docs.lead_paragraph: Despite fears that the nation's unemployment rate could climb back into double digits because of the heavy snowstorms in February, the latest figures show that it remained nearly steady at 9.7 percent last month.
docs.abstract: The Labor Department releases its monthly statistics, figures that Republicans quickly pounce on as evidence that the administration's economic agenda isn't working.

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

headline.main: How Much Fraud and Abuse Is There in U.S. Health Care?

docs.abstract: There's unlikely to be much in hospital systems, an economist writes. But the extraordinary administrative burden created to weed it out helps drive up the cost of care.

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG  and ROBERT PEAR

docs.lead_paragraph: Perhaps the most overlooked section of President Obama's speech on health care Wednesday was his insistence that the Democratic bill would take sufficient steps to control the rise in health care costs for individuals, families and the federal government. ''We have now incorporated most of the serious ideas from across the political spectrum about how to contain the rising cost of health care -- ideas that go after the waste and abuse in our system, especially in programs like Medicare,'' he said.
docs.abstract: Most overlooked section of Pres Obama's speech on health care was his insistence that Democratic bill would take sufficient steps to control rise in health care costs for individuals, families and federal government; Obama's remarks sent clear message to crucial group of Congressional Democrats who voted against health care legislation citing cost concerns: White House and Congressional leaders will not be taking any big new steps to win them over (M)
docs.snippet: Perhaps the most overlooked section of President Obama's speech on health care Wednesday was his insistence that the Democratic bill would take sufficient steps to control the rise in health care costs for individuals, families and the federal...

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Medical Association last week released its annual study examining competition in the health insurance market. The verdict: Competition is dwindling. In 24 of the 43 states studied, the two biggest insurers together covered at least 70 percent of the market. Paul B. Ginsburg, president of the Center for Studying Health System Change in Washington, spoke with Michelle Andrews about the availability of insurance. Here is an edited excerpt.
docs.abstract: Excerpt from Michelle Andrews interview with Paul B Ginsburg, president of Center for Studying Health System Change, about availability of health insurance (S)
